data.text: Our group started riding gravel with our road bikes. Mostly CF frames. One steel. Last year 5 of us moved to dedicated gravel bikes. 4 went Ti, 1 went CF. The Ti buyers decided based on extensive chipping of CF finish and steel bike paint. The CF buyer was going for a lighter and faster rig. Ti brand? 2 Moots and 2 Litespeed. Both solid brands. Checking geometry and construction features will probably make the decision for you. The Moots are expensive, but both have 2 wheelsets for good road and gravel performance and get ridden a lot. Over the long haul will be reasonable cost per mile. One of the Moots is mine, a Routt 45. Its geometry is very well judged, construction is meticulous, and ride is exceptionally solid and confidence inspiring. Have ridden it in all conditions, well beyond the normal gravel envelope and into MB territory. Would not hesitate to ride it anywhere anytime.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Additional comment. IMO geometry is more important than material. Probably a good part of why I like the Moots is that we learned from the geometry of two custom bikes, years of position adjustment, and a fitting before it. A CF frame might happen to have the right geometry. Or maybe not. A potential Ti advantage is that you can get custom geo.

data.text: So, I have a Ti road bike and I love it. However, I would hesitate to get a Ti gravel bike for the same reason that I would hesitate to get a Ti MTB: things change super quickly with these types of bikes, standards, etc., and pretty quickly you might find yourself with a beautiful bike that no replacement parts are available for. Not that things don't change in the roadbike realm, but there is more history and likely future availability of parts that are standard roadbike fare. My No.22 Great Divide road bike is rimbrake, but I'm not terribly worried that wheels won't be available in future, as there are so many rimbrake bikes still in use. Might change in 20 years, but it won't be my problem so much, then!
